title: Ringan Gilhaize, or, The Covenanters
author: Galt, John
snippet: So, taking his wife andAgnes Kilspinnie with him, he went in the spring to Edinburgh, and hireda lodging for them; and on the same night he presented himself at thelodging of the Lord James Stuart, who had some time before been createdEarl of Murray; but the Earl was gone with the Queen to Loch Leven.

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: Death, at all times, is a solemn thing, and but few have the fortitude to witness its sure approach without a shudder, and none to welcome it with more calmness than did the gentle and talented poet of Loch Leven.

title: Around the clock in Europe;
author: Howell, Charles Fish.
snippet: Scotland seems unrolled at your feet and Scottish songs rush to mind until you fairly bound the region in verse and story : To the north and northwest, "Bonnie Dundee," the glens of "Clan Alpine's warriors true," Bannockburn and " Scots wha hae wi' Wallace bled," and "The Banks of Allan Water"; to the north and east, the Firth of Forth where the fishwives' " puir fellows darkle as they face the billows"; to the west and southwest, "The banks and braes o' bonnie Doon," "Tam o'Shanter's " land, " Sweet Aston" and "Bonnie Loch Leven" whence "the Camp- bells are comin'"; and to the south, "The braes of Yarrow,"  " Norham's castled steep, Tweed's fair river, broad and deep, and Cheviot's mountains lone," and, most sung of all, "The Border": —

title: A brief account of a tour through some parts of Scotland
author: Hunter, Robert
snippet: Passage to Dundee—Some account of the town—Arbroath—Arrival at Montrose—Description of the town—Excursioninto the country—Aor/A Esk—Den of Fenella—Cascade—Grampians — Lawrencekirk — Fettercairn — Agreeableentertainment in the /nn — Blind Peter, an interestingcharacter—Castle of Balbegie—Estate of Burns—Arrivalat Brechin, and return to Montrose — Scotch marriageceremonies—Funerals—Horticultural society—Aberdeen—Return to Leith i>y Cupar and Kirkcaldy — Stirling —Kinross — Loch Leven, with its Castle, in which QueenMary was imprisoned—Return to Whitby — Conclusion

title: A Tour in Tartan-Land

snippet: Its name appears tohave been derived from the British word Llummon,'a beacon;' and, in the thirteenth century, the mountain lent its name to the lake, which had previouslybeen called Loch Leven, still retained by the riverwhich flows out of the lake into the Clyde at Dumbarton.
